0.text:
As of 2015 there are roughly 4,200 religions
in the world - some are thousands of years

9.text:
old and there are new ones being created all
the time. Here’s seven extremely bizarre

15.text:
religions that sound completely made up, but
they’re not.

22.text:
Let’s begin with the biggest religion in
our list. In 2001, thanks to each country

28.text:
completing a census of their populations,
this religion was found to be the second biggest

34.text:
in New Zealand and the fourth biggest in England
and Wales. Any guess as to what it might be?

41.text:
Strange the answer is; it’s Jedi
Yes, around 1.5% of Kiwi’s put Jedi or Jediism

47.text:
as their official religion. 58.9% put Christian
and then the next two spots were “No Religion”

55.text:
and “Object to answering”, so that puts
Jediism as the number two religion in New

61.text:
Zealand; unless “object to answering”
is a religion, there’s probably no point

66.text:
in asking them if it is though.
In England and Wales 0.8% of the country claimed

72.text:
their religion was Jediism, with the only
larger faiths being Christianity, Islam, and

78.text:
Hinduism. So, how did this all come about?
A long long time ago, in a country not very

84.text:
far away, the galactic council, I mean the
national governments of many commonwealth

88.text:
countries, let everyone know they would be
having a census. Many people on the internet

94.text:
decided they didn’t want to tell the government
about their religion and so one of the first

99.text:
online viral phenomena began, with people
spreading the idea of saying they were Jedi

107.text:
When you look at their beliefs, it’s actually
all pleasantly positive. They obviously believe

112.text:
in the force, and the inherent worth of all
life within it, and much of the rest is just

116.text:
about not discriminating, being logical and,
I’m guessing here, never ever talking about

122.text:
The Phantom Menace in public.
Their doctrines have actually allowed them

126.text:
to be a fully recognised international ministry
and a publicly registered charity. So if you’ve

133.text:
got some spare galactic credits lying around,
you know where to send them.

136.text:
There are some people who you can imagine
being mistaken for gods; Ryan Gosling with

142.text:
his annoyingly handsome face, chess champion
Bobby Fischer with his godlike intelligence

147.text:
and quick thinking, or maybe Hugh Jackman
if you saw him chopping wood high up a mountain.

153.text:
But none of these people have an actual religious
following. The unlikely man who does however,

160.text:
is Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh and husband
to Queen Elizabeth the second. And his followers

166.text:
are not some extreme British nationalists,
they are, in fact, inhabitants of a small

172.text:
island called Tanna, part of the Republic
of Vanuatu.

178.text:
Vanuatu is a chain of islands in the South
Pacific, just under 2000 km east of Northern

185.text:
Australia. Tanna is one of the 82 odd islands
and is populated mainly by Melanesians, a

191.text:
pacific island people of similar origin to
the Australian Aboriginals. An old myth exists

197.text:
on the island about a spirit ancestor who
had run off across the seas to find himself

202.text:
a powerful wife. So when Prince Philip visited
the island in 1974, arm in arm with her Royal

209.text:
Majesty, one of the most powerful women in
the world, they decided that he fitted the

214.text:
bill and declared him to be their god. I imagine
he endured a similar fate as C-3PO did under

221.text:
the hospitality of the Ewoks, during his visit
to Endor.

224.text:
Prince Philip, being the affable man that
he is, sent them a signed photograph. In return

230.text:
they sent him a club for killing pigs. I can
neither confirm nor deny if this had any connection

236.text:
to the increase in bacon consumption at Buckingham
Palace that year.

239.text:
Prophet Jack, the Prince Philip Movement’s
soothsaying religious leader, has claimed

245.text:
that a devastating cyclone, which came to
the island in early 2015, was a holy sign

250.text:
that the great Prince himself will be returning
to the island in 2016. We’ll just have to

256.text:
wait and see.
So for our next religion we have to travel

261.text:
all the way to… actually we don’t need
to travel at all, we’re staying on the island

265.text:
of Tanna.
Vanautu has a number of Cargo Cults. These

270.text:
are Melanesian movements that originated from
the native people coming into contact with

274.text:
the colonising societies who visited the Islands.
On Tanna, about 50% of the population are

281.text:
part of the Cargo Cult called John Frum, which
allegedly started with the visons of some

287.text:
elders in the late 1930s and became cemented
when the American troops came during WWII.

293.text:
The name is said to come from when a soldier
told the natives that he was “John from

298.text:
America” The people saw all the wonderful
cargo that these troops brought, such as lorries,

304.text:
radios and the world’s most iconic brand;
Coca Cola. When the soldiers left, the people

309.text:
knew that John Frum would return some day
and share his wonderful bounty with them all.

315.text:
In a way, they were right, since the island
now boasts an airport and some infrastructure

321.text:
for education, as well as a variety of western
brands. The people are very grateful and they

326.text:
share evenly amongst their community. February
15th is known as “John Frum Day”, the

332.text:
date which they believe John Frum will return
to the island. They celebrate John Frum Day,

338.text:
with a military-like parade, marching through
the island, carrying the stars and stripes

342.text:
and scrawling “USA” on their chests in
red paint. Throw in some fireworks and beer

347.text:
pong and it’s basically the 4th of July.
Our next religion is followed by a large number

352.text:
of atheists. I know what you’re thinking;
how can you have a religion for people who

358.text:
don’t believe in religion? Well the Pastafarians
have a pretty good reason.

365.text:
Pastafarianism came about in 2005 when Bobby
Henderson discussed The Flying Spaghetti Monster

372.text:
in an open letter to the Kansas State Board
of Education. This God is a sort of floating

377.text:
blob of wobbly noodles and meatballs. If this
all sounds very silly, it’s supposed to

383.text:
be. He came up with the idea in order to fight
against the decision to allow Creationism

388.text:
to be taught in schools, thanks to the campaigning
of Christian groups.

391.text:
For those of you not familiar with the argument;
Atheists agree with the large consensus of

397.text:
scientists who believe that the universe is
around 14 billion years old, with Earth being

402.text:
formed about four and a half billion years
ago, and that life has grown and diversified

407.text:
through evolution; with the smallest amoebas
eventually leading to us, the pinnacle of

413.text:
human evolution. Creationists believe that
God created the world around 10,000 years

418.text:
ago and that each creature was made as it
is now. It’s called Intelligent Design and

424.text:
it argues against evolution.
Pastafarian’s beef (and whatever other meats

430.text:
their noodly deity contains,) with creationism
being taught in schools, is that it violates

436.text:
the secular nature of the laws of the USA.
There is supposed to be a complete separation

441.text:
of church and state, and this includes schools.
Creationism is a religious idea, specific

448.text:
to a few religions, not to all of them, therefore
it shouldn’t be part of state education.

455.text:
To prove this, Bobby Henderson argued that
he believed a supernatural Italian dinner

460.text:
was the world creator and that whenever a
scientist tried to carbon date an object,

465.text:
to see how old it was, this god was there
“changing the results with his noodly appendage”.

471.text:
He said his beliefs were just as valid as
Creationists, therefore should be included

477.text:
in the curriculum as well.
The idea took hold and spread around the internet

483.text:
and the Church of the Flying Spaghetti Monster
has many followers, allegedly leading back

487.text:
to pirates, who were the original Pastafarians.
I’m sure you’ll all be very worried to

493.text:
know that they think the decline in the number
of pirates is a direct cause of global warming.

499.text:
Only the release of another 18 Jack Sparrow
films will start to reverse this trend.

505.text:
So, from extra pasta sauce to extra-terrestrials;
let’s have a look of one of the many UFO

511.text:
religions that sprung up in the second half
of the 20th century.

516.text:
Universe People, also called Cosmic People
of Light Powers, is a group that believe a

521.text:
fleet of spaceships float around the earth
where they subtly intervene in the lives of

525.text:
the good, assisting them on their way. And
some day the Ashtar Galactic Command, who

530.text:
lead the ships, will pick up the believers
and send them off to another wonderful dimension.

536.text:
Most of the followers are based in the Czech
Republic and in Slovakia, thanks to the religion’s

541.text:
founder Ivo A. Benda, whose name sounds like
the punchline to a politically incorrect joke.

547.text:
In 1997 he published the delightfully titled
Interviews With Instructions From My Friends

553.text:
From the Universe and he used this as a platform
to begin touring with a series of public lectures.

559.text:
He eventually made his way onto national TV
in both the Czech Republic and Slovakia.

565.text:
In the late 2000s, Benda began to realise
that the alien world, much like Earth, contained

571.text:
both helpful and harmful people. The Saurians,
or Lizard people, were out to get us, and

578.text:
Benda was going to do his best to stop them.
It was all very reminiscent of the classic

583.text:
Czech novel War with the Newts by Karel Capek,
where the salamanders end up turning on mankind.

590.text:
In 2007, Benda’s plan caused a security
alert at the Slovak ministry of defence when

597.text:
his suspicious protection packages arrived,
containing instructional CDs and promotional

603.text:
material. But if a man can’t protect his
country from large alien lizards with a recorded

609.text:
lecture and some fliers, then how else is
he supposed to do it?

613.text:
He still fights the good fight and you can
see what he’s up to on his website; universe-people.com.

620.text:
Just to warn you, you might want to put on
sunglasses before you enter; it’s more colourful

623.text: than a teenage unicorn’s sock collection.

626.text:
Now I’m not saying lizard people are real,
but if they are, I’m pretty sure our next

631.text: religious leader is one of them.

633.text:
Happy Science was founded in 1986 by the rather
reptilian-looking Ryuho Okawa. He had read

641.text:
an inspiring series of books by Takahashi
Shinji, no I’m not talking about the baseball

646.text:
player, but the other famous Takahashi Shinji
who is leader of the God Light Association.

653.text:
The books had a big impact on Mr Okawa and
made him see that he was actually the living

659.text:
embodiment of, among others, Christ, Buddah
and Allah. It was a tough decision but he

666.text:
realised that since he was an omnipotent super
god, he was probably over-qualified for his

671.text:
job at a large Japanese trading company, good
job though it was.

674.text:
So he resigned and began spreading the good
word that he was in fact the great super-deity;

679.text:
“El Cantare”. The fact that this means
“the singer” in Spanish, is just a cosmic

685.text:
coincidence.
To be a Happy Scientist, you need to focus

689.text:
on the fourfold paths of Love, Wisdom, Self-Reflection
and Progress, no actual scientific knowledge

696.text:
is required, so don’t worry if you’ve
forgotten all your chemistry. You might need

700.text:
to forget some of your history though, as
El Cantare has told us that certain parts

705.text:
of Japanese history, such as the odd massacre
of two, definitely didn’t happen.

710.text:
The politics don’t end there since the political
wing, called The Happiness Realisation Party,

717.text:
was set up in 2009 and received a rather surprising
1 million votes across Japan’s 300 constituencies.

725.text:
They didn’t end up with any seats though.
The main focus of their campaign was to double

729.text:
the Japanese population and to develop a nuclear
deterrent to threaten China and North Korea.

735.text:
They really don’t like China and North Korea.
I’m not sure that nuclear weapons are exactly

740.text:
what I would call Happy Science but hey, I’m
not the flamenco god of the universe so what

746.text:
do I know, right?
Our final religion has a much darker history

751.text:
than the others. It’s all fun and games
when it’s British princes, lizard men and

756.text:
El Cantare, but when your cult leads to murder
and mass suicide, that’s a whole different

763.text:
The Order of the Solar Temple was set up in
1984 by Joseph di Mambro and Luc Jouret and

769.text:
was a continuation of other groups Di Mambro
had been in and founded in the previous decade

774.text:
or so. They started out in Switzerland and
moved to a headquarters in Quebec, Canada,

780.text:
in the late eighties.
The religion was based on a mix of sources,

783.text:
the main one being the famous Knights Templar.
Their idea was to reassert the correct balance

789.text:
of power in the world and to lay the way for
the second coming of Christ, the Solar King.

795.text:
They also took inspiration from notorious
British occultist, Aleister Crowley.

800.text:
The Order’s dark side was revealed to the
world on October 1994, with deaths on both

805.text:
sides of the Atlantic. A couple and a young
baby where killed in Quebec, with rumours

811.text:
that Di Mambro had accused the child of being
the Antichrist. A few days later, in Switzerland,

817.text:
both Di Mambro and Jouret were found dead
along with 46 other cult-members. Not only

824.text:
that but the bodies were discovered, arranged
in a disturbing sun-shaped pattern on the

829.text:
floor. The true story will never be uncovered
but many of the group had been drugged, some

836.text:
were shot, some suffocated with bags over
their heads and both buildings were on fire.

842.text:
Unfortunately, it didn’t end with the death
of the founders, and there were further mass

846.text:
killings in 95 and 97. It transpired that
mass murders and group ritual suicides were

853.text:
all part and parcel of being a member of the
Order of the Solar Temple.

859.text: No thanks, I'm going to join the Jedi instead.
